thread.title: Tory MPs will do anything to avoid an election because they don’t want a Labour Government

author: Ben Bradshaw
title: Tory MPs will do anything to avoid an election because they don’t want a Labour Government
text:
News opinion Tory MPs will do anything to avoid an election because they don’t want a Labour Government Ben Bradshaw MP says there’s still a long way to go in this damaging Brexit saga and is getting an increasing postbag over the handling of Brexit Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get Daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email
BEN BRADSHAW IS THE LABOUR MP FOR EXETER AND HAS BEEN SINCE 1997
The governor of the Bank of England told MPs this week that households are at least £900 a year worse off and the economy £40 billion smaller as a result of the Brexit vote.
Mark Carney said the economy is two percent lower than it would have been and has been damaged by uncertainty, which has deterred business investment, and inflation, which has squeezed household incomes.
His comments were immediately rubbished by Conservative hard Brexiteers Boris Johnson and Jacob Rees Mogg. The Chancellor, Philip Hammond, however, did not contest them. Ben Bradshaw MP
We are nearly two years on from the EU Referendum with less than a year to go before we are scheduled to leave. But we still don’t know what the Government actually wants. Mr Rees Mogg described Mrs May’s preferred “Customs Partnership” idea as “cretinous”. Mr Johnson said it was “crazy”. Read More There will be no hard border between the north and south in Ireland
Meanwhile, I’m getting an ever growing postbag from Exeter businesses and other organisations worried about the Government’s handling of Brexit.
Exeter Federation of Small Businesses tells me their most pressing problem is the worsening labour shortage. Exeter’s neighbouring Conservative MP, Neil Parish, has warned of a serious shortage of seasonal workers from Eastern Europe to pick crops. Marsh Barton car dealerships, local florists and other business who rely on the quick and easy flow of goods or services are worried about new trade barriers. Green groups and health organisations fear the watering down of existing environmental and food safety laws. The Royal College of Nursing is so worried about the staffing crisis in the NHS and Social Care that it has called for a Referendum on the terms of any Brexit deal. Ben Bradshaw after increasing his majority in May
Very soon Mrs May will have to spell out what she wants. If she caves in to the hard Brexiteers, she won’t get her deal through the Commons. If she faces them down, they have threatened to get rid of her and even force another general election. Read More No surprise that record numbers of European nurses and midwives are quitting Britain
They’re bluffing. Tory MPs will do anything to avoid an election because they don’t want a Labour Government. And, if Mrs May were ousted by a hard Brexiteer, her successor would find it even harder to assemble a Commons majority to get a hard Brexit through.
However, that does not mean the Government is out of the woods. It could well lose important votes in the next few weeks on a Customs Union and other parts of its Brexit legislation. Then there’ll be the all-important crunch vote on any deal, supposedly in the autumn, although there are reports that the Government might try to delay this to the New Year. If the Government loses that vote, all bets are off. There’s still a long way to go in this damaging Brexit saga, I’m afraid.
